name: Mathematical Models in Physics
description: Exploring advanced mathematical techniques used to describe fundamental physical laws.

cards.title: Lagrangian & Hamiltonian Mechanics
cards.description: Understanding the foundations of analytical mechanics and action principles.
bulletpoints: The Lagrangian is defined as: \[ L = T - V \], where \( T \) is kinetic energy and \( V \) is potential energy
Euler-Lagrange equation: \[ \frac{d}{dt} \left( \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}} \right) - \frac{\partial L}{\partial q} = 0 \]
Hamiltonian function: \[ H = \sum_{i} p_i \dot{q}_i - L \], defining phase space dynamics
Applications in classical mechanics, quantum mechanics, and field theory.
cards.summaryText: Formulate dynamics with Lagrangians and Hamiltonians, applying Euler-Lagrange and phase-space tools across physics.

cards.title: Chaos Theory & Nonlinear Dynamics
cards.description: Investigating deterministic chaos, attractors, and complexity in physical systems.
bulletpoints: Sensitive dependence on initial conditions: Lyapunov exponent \( \lambda > 0 \)
Logistic map: \[ x_{n+1} = r x_n (1 - x_n) \], showing chaotic behavior for certain \( r \)
Lorenz system: \[ \dot{x} = \sigma(y-x), \quad \dot{y} = x(\rho - z) - y, \quad \dot{z} = xy - \beta z \], producing strange attractors.
Applications to fluid dynamics, astrophysics, and climate models.
cards.summaryText: Study Lyapunov growth, logistic maps, and Lorenz attractors to understand chaotic physical systems.

cards.title: Statistical Mechanics & Thermodynamic Notation
cards.description: Exploring the mathematical models behind entropy, heat transfer, and statistical ensembles.
bulletpoints: Entropy: \[ S = k_B \ln \Omega \], where \( k_B \) is Boltzmann's constant
Partition function: \[ Z = \sum_{i} e^{-E_i / k_B T} \], essential in canonical ensembles
Thermodynamic identities: \[ dU = TdS - PdV \], \[ dF = -SdT - PdV \]
Maxwell's relations in thermodynamics: \[ \left( \frac{\partial S}{\partial V} \right)_T = \left( \frac{\partial P}{\partial T} \right)_V \]
cards.summaryText: Use entropy, partition functions, and thermodynamic identities to derive ensemble-level predictions.

cards.title: Quantum Field Theory & Gauge Invariance
cards.description: Mathematical formalism underlying particle physics and gauge theories.
bulletpoints: Dirac equation for relativistic quantum mechanics: \[ (i \gamma^\mu \partial_\mu - m) \psi = 0 \]
Gauge transformation in electromagnetism: \[ A_\mu \to A_\mu + \partial_\mu \Lambda \]
Path integral formulation: \[ Z = \int \mathcal{D}\phi \, e^{i S/\hbar} \], where S is the action.
Feynman diagrams describe quantum interactions using propagators and vertices.
cards.summaryText: Frame quantum fields via Dirac equations, gauge symmetry, path integrals, and Feynman diagrams.

cards.title: Fluid Dynamics & Navier-Stokes Equations
cards.description: Mathematical modeling of fluid motion in various physical contexts.
bulletpoints: Continuity equation: \[ \frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t} + \nabla \cdot (\rho \mathbf{v}) = 0 \]
Navier-Stokes equation: \[ \rho \left( \frac{D \mathbf{v}}{Dt} \right) = - \nabla P + \mu \nabla^2 \mathbf{v} + \rho \mathbf{g} \]
Euler's equation for inviscid flow: \[ \frac{D\mathbf{v}}{Dt} = -\frac{1}{\rho} \nabla P \]
Bernoulli's theorem: \[ P + \frac{1}{2} \rho v^2 + \rho gh = \text{constant} \]
cards.summaryText: Model fluids with continuity, Navier-Stokes, Euler, and Bernoulli relations to capture flow behavior.
